duck: Triangulation (surveying) refers to measurement by using triangles. Triangulation may also refer to:
Triangulation (social science), the use of multiple cross-checked sources and methodology
triangulation definition: the measurement of the elements necessary to determine the network of triangles into which any part of the earth's surface is divided in surveying; '''broadly'''.

wiki.text:
.]] In trigonometry and geometry, 'triangulation' is the process of determining
the location of a point by measuring angles to it from known points at either
end of a fixed baseline, rather than measuring distances to the point directly
(trilateration). The point can then be fixed as the third point of a triangle
with one known side and two known angles.

Triangulation can also refer to the accurate surveying of systems of very large
triangles, called 'triangulation networks'. This followed from the work of
Willebrord Snell in 1615–17, who showed how a point could be located from the
angles subtended from three known points, but measured at the new unknown point
rather than the previously fixed points, a problem called resectioning.
Surveying error is minimized if a mesh of triangles at the largest appropriate
scale is established first. Points inside the triangles can all then be
accurately located with reference to it. Such triangulation methods were used
for accurate large-scale land surveying until the rise of global navigation
satellite systems in the 1980s.
